thread.title: Thousands turn out for 5K, carrying secrets and more
thread.title_full: Thousands turn out for 5K, carrying secrets and more

author: freep.com
title: Thousands turn out for 5K, carrying secrets and more
text:
MORE Temperatures hovered just above freezing Saturday morning in Detroit, but firefighter Roger Dyjak was sweating.
He ran a 5K wearing 40 pounds of gear.
“I wanted to be able to train so if I need to save a life, I can do it better,” he said. “Because every second counts.”
Dyjak, 43, who works and lives in Memphis, Mich., said running in the gear, including 10-pound boots, was as hard as completing a marathon, which he has also done.
DETROIT FREE PRESS
Free Press Marathon: Everything you need to know
Bill Ewing, operations director, estimated more than 2,000 people participated in the American Home Fitness 5K on Saturday, which started near the Outdoor Adventure Center and William G. Milliken State Park and Harbor along the Detroit RiverWalk. It is one of many events leading up to Sunday's 38th Detroit Free Press/Talmer Bank Marathon in Detroit.
Some of those who turned out Saturday were avid runners. Others, like 61-year-old Bart Passalacqua, ran a 5K for the first time.
DETROIT FREE PRESS
Detroit Free Press/Talmer Bank Marathon Health & Fitness Expo
He crossed the finish line with his 34-year-old daughter, who had a surprise for him: She’s expecting her first baby.
Anna Beernaert of Livonia wore a black shirt underneath her running gear. On it, a fetus over her stomach with the words “WORKOUT BUDDY” underneath, which she revealed to her dad.
Buy Photo Bart Passalacqua, 61, of Plymouth Township kisses his daughter Anna Beernaert, 34, of Livonia after they both finished the American Home Fitness 5K on Oct. 17, 2015. (Photo: Eric Seals, Detroit Free Press)
“I’m very proud,” said Passalacqua of Plymouth Township, shortly after he found out.
About three months ago, he had a dream his daughter was pregnant, he recalled.
Saturday also marked the first time Leronn Wilson, 25, of Detroit finished a 5K. For him, it was about fitness.
“I didn’t quit,” he said. “That was the biggest thing.”
Some runners sported green and white, or maize and blue, leaving no doubt who they'd be rooting for this afternoon during the intrastate rivalry college football game.
Suzanne Cady, 39, of Trenton wore a green Spartans windbreaker, while her friend, Gerald Gonzales, 43, of Belleville wore a Wolverine shirt and an ear warmer with the letter M on it.
After the 5K, children participated in the Meijer Kids Fun Run wearing tutus, furry hats and painted faces.
Some of the runners Saturday also plan to participate in the marathon on Sunday.
Contact Elisha Anderson: eanderson@freepress.com or 313-222-5144, Follow on Twitter: @elishaanderson
